tit.cmt: 統一用語リストAzukaridokoro (a deputy of "Shoen" manor lord)のカッコ内は省略しました。

sen.j: 預所（あずかりどころ/あずけしょ/あずがっそ/あずかりしょ）とは、中世の荘園において本所の補任を受けて在地を統括した職の体系。
sen.e: Azukaridokoro/Azukesho/Azugasso/Azukarissho (預所) was a deputy position in the job system in the medieval Shoen manor, and integrally controlled it with the official appointment of honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor).
sen.cmt: （あずかりどころ/あずけしょ/あずがっそ/あずかりしょ）と読み方が複数あるので/区切りすべてローマ字表記しました。「(預所) was a deputy position」 と統一用語リストAzukaridokoro (a deputy of "Shoen" manor lord)の表現のdeputyをここで補いました。
sen.e: Azukaridokoro (also Azukesho, Azugasso, Azukarissho) was a deputy position the medieval Shoen manor, and integrally controlled it with the official appointment of honjo (proprietor or guarantor of a manor).

"Azukaridokoro" (also Azukesho, Azugasso, Azukarisho) was a deputy position the medieval Shoen manor, and integrally controlled it with the official appointment of honjo (proprietor or guarantor of a manor).
sen.cmt: 統一リスト（その他 2009/6/29）の指示により、Azukaridokoro にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。Azukarissho を Azukarisho に修正しました。

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の法制書である『沙汰未練書』には「預所者本所御領所務代官也（預所は本所の御領における所務代官である）」と記されている。
sen.e: In a legal code book, "Satamirensho" published in the Kamakura Period, it is defined as 'Azukaridokoro is the local clerical manager in the manor entrusted by honjo.'
sen.cmt: 法制書→定訳不明：legal code bookとしました。
sen.e: In a legal code book, "Satamirensho" published in the Kamakura Period, it is defined as 'Azukaridokoro is the local clerical manager in the manor entrusted by honjo.'
In a legal code book, "Satamirensho" published in the Kamakura Period, it is defined as 'Azukaridokoro is the local clerical manager in the manor entrusted by honjo.'

sen.j: 12世紀頃から従来の専当・預 (官職)・検校・定使などに代わって出現した。
sen.e: Since around the 12th century, it emerged to take the place of traditional sento (a person who does practical business in the management of Shoen estates), azukari (government post), kengyo (one of shokans, officers governing Shoen manor), jotsukai (la lower-ranked officer who governs Shoen manor).
sen.cmt: 専当→sento (a person who does practical business in the management of Shoen estates) 預 →定訳不明：azukari としました。 官職→government post 検校→kengyo (one of shokans, officers governing Shoen manor) 定使→ｊotsukai (la lower-ranked officer who governs Shoen manor)
sen.e: Since around the 12th century, it emerged to take the place of traditional sento (a person who does practical business in the management of Shoen estates), azukari (government post), kengyo (one of shokans, officers governing Shoen manor), and jotsukai (la lower-ranked officer who governs Shoen manor).

Since around the 12th century, it emerged to take the place of traditional sento (a person who does practical business in the management of Shoen estates), azukari (government post), kengyo (one of shokans, officers governing Shoen manor), and jotsukai (a lower-ranked officer who governs Shoen manor).
sen.cmt: (la lower-ranked officer who・・・ の la を a に修正しました。

sen.j: ただし、記録・文献上に現れる預所は様々な地位・職掌にあったことが知られている。
sen.e: However, Azukaridokoro appeared in the records and references shows that its position and scope of work varied widely.
However, records and references show that the position and scope of Azukaridokoro varied widely.
However, records and references show that the position and scope of Azukaridokoro varied widely.

sen.j: 一般的な預所は本所の補任を受けて在地において下司・公文などの下級荘官を指揮して経営にあたっていた。
sen.e: Azukaridokoro in general, with the appointed by honjo, took charge of management of the Shoen manor, directing the lower-ranked shokans (officers governing the manor).
Azukaridokoro in general, appointed by honjo, took charge of management of the Shoen manor, directing the lower-ranked shokans (officers governing the manor).
sen.cmt: “with the appointed” makes no sense in this usage
sen.e: Azukaridokoro in general, appointed by honjo, took charge of management of the Shoen manor, directing the lower-ranked shokans (officers governing the manor).

sen.j: 在地における預所では本所より派遣された者や現地の有力者、開発領主・寄進者本人（または子孫などの関係者）が任じられることが多かった。
sen.e: To Azukaridokoro in the manor, an officer dispatched from honjo, influential local person, Kaihatsu ryoshu (local noble who actually developed the land), or the donator himself of the manor (or his descendent or a related person) were often appointed.
sen.cmt: 寄進者本人→定訳不明：the donator himself of the manor としました。
sen.e: To Azukaridokoro in the manor, an officer dispatched from honjo, an influential local person, Kaihatsu ryoshu (local noble who actually developed the land), or the benefactor of the manor (or his descendent or a related person) were often appointed.

To Azukaridokoro in the manor, an officer dispatched from honjo, an influential local person, Kaihatsu ryoshu (local noble who actually developed the land), or the benefactor of the manor (or his descendent or a related person) were often appointed.

sen.j: だが、一方において、本家-領家といった重層的な荘園領主が存在する荘園では本家が本所である場合、領家のことを預所と称した。
sen.e: However, on the other hand, in case that honke (head family) was the proprietor (honjo) of a Shoen manor, and there existed a multi-layered structure in lord of the manor, such as honke-ryoke (lord of the manor) relationship, the ryoke was called Azukaridokoro.

However, on the other hand, in case that the honke (head family) was also the proprietor (honjo) of a Shoen manor, and there existed a multi-layered structure in control of the manor, such as honke-ryoke relationships, the ryoke was called Azukaridokoro.
sen.cmt: the parenthetical “lord of manor” wasn't helping this sentence any
sen.e: However, on the other hand, in case of a Shoen manor where existed a multi-layered structure in control such as the honke (patron) and the ryoke (proprietor), the ryoke was called Azukaridokoro.
sen.cmt: "that the honke (head family) was also the proprietor (honjo) of a Shoen manor, and there existed a multi-layered structure in control of the manor, such as honke-ryoke relationships, "を全文書き換えました。※この場合の「本家-領家」とは"head family"ではなく、 "the patron and the proprietor" のことと思われます。参考：http://books.google.com/books?id=ijyj-9lHNigC&pg=PA289&dq=honke+ryoke&lr=&as_brr=3&hl=ja&cd=16#v=onepage&q=honke%20ryoke&f=false

sen.j: 更に本家が自己の家司などを預所に任じて知行させ俸禄の代わりにした場合もあった。
sen.e: In addition, there were cases in which the honke appointed its own Keishi (household superintendent) or other its retainer to Azukaridokori through the enfeoffment, so that this person could be benefited by the manor instead of receiving his horoku (salary).

In addition, there were cases in which the honke appointed its own Keishi (household superintendent) or other retainer to Azukaridokori, so that he could be supported by the manor instead of receiving his salary.

In addition, there were cases in which the honke appointed its own Keishi (household superintendent) or other retainer to Azukaridokori, so that he could be supported by the manor instead of receiving his salary.

sen.j: 領家や家司が預所になった場合には在京のままその地位を占めることが多く、実際の経営は彼らに任ぜられた代官などが行っていた。
sen.e: When a ryoke or a Keishi became Azukaridokoro, in many cases, this person continued living in Kyoto even taking the position, and the practical management was carried out by daikan (deputy officer) etc., entrusted by him.
sen.cmt: 代官→定訳不明：daikan (deputy officer)としました。 *統一用語リストにはｄaikan (local governor)とありますが、文脈上当てはまらないようなので採用しませんでした。
sen.e: When a ryoke or a Keishi became Azukaridokoro, in many cases, he continued living in Kyoto, and day to day management was carried out by a trusted deputy.
When a ryoke or a Keishi became Azukaridokoro, in many cases, he continued living in Kyoto, and day to day management was carried out by a trusted deputy.

sen.j: 前者のような在地の預所を「在地預所」、後者のような京都に居住する（従って現地には赴かない）預所を「在京預所」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The former type of local Azukaridokoro is called "Zaichi Azukaridokoro" (Azukaridokoro in the duty station), and the latter type of Azukaridokoro living in Kyoto (that means they did not go to the duty station or outliers) is called "Zaikyo Azukaridokoro" (Azukaridokoro in Kyoto).
sen.cmt: 「在地預所」→定訳不明"Zaichi Azukaridokoro" (Azukaridokoro in the duty station)としました。
sen.e: The former type of local Azukaridokoro is called "Zaichi Azukaridokoro" (Azukaridokoro in the duty station), and the latter type of Azukaridokoro living in Kyoto is called "Zaikyo Azukaridokoro".
sen.cmt: “azukaridokoro in Kyoto” was redundant with “azukaridokoro living in Kyoto”
sen.e: The former type of local Azukaridokoro is called "Zaichi Azukaridokoro" (Azukaridokoro in the duty station), and the latter type of Azukaridokoro living in Kyoto is called "Zaikyo Azukaridokoro".

sen.j: 重層的な荘園領主の構造の中では、在地預所と在京預所の両方が存在する場合もあり得、その場合は下級荘官である下司に対して前者を中司、後者を上司と称した。
sen.e: Within the multi-layered structure of Shoen ryoshu, in some cases, both of Zaichi Azukaridokoro and Zaikyo Azukaridokoro coexisted, an in such cases, the former was called Chushi (中司), and the latter was called 上司Joshi (上司), after the denomination Geshi (local keeper) which was used for low-ranked shokan.
sen.cmt: 中司→Chushi (中司) [正しい読み方が不明です] 上司→Joshi (上司) [正しい読み方が不明です]
sen.e: Within the multi-layered structure of Shoen ryoshu, in some cases, both Zaichi Azukaridokoro and Zaikyo Azukaridokoro coexisted, and in such cases, the former was called Chushi, and the latter was called Joshi, after the Geshi (local keeper) which was a low-ranked shokan.

Within the multi-layered structure of Shoen ryoshu, in some cases, both Zaichi Azukaridokoro and Zaikyo Azukaridokoro coexisted, and in such cases, the former was called Chushi, and the latter was called Joshi, after the Geshi (local keeper) which was a low-ranked shokan.

sen.j: 平安時代末期には本来は事務官的な要素の強い預所に武士が就く例も増加し、そのまま地頭や在地領主の地位を得る例も現れた。
sen.e: At the late Heian Period, an increasing number of samurais began to take the position of Azukaridokoro, which was originally a clerical post though, and there appeared some samurais, who in continuation, went up the ladder to acquire the post of Jito (manager and lord of manor) or Zaichi ryoshu (local lord).

At the late Heian Period, an increasing number of samurais began to take positions as Azukaridokoro, although it was originally a clerical post, and some continued to advance to acquire the post of Jito (manager and lord of manor) or Zaichi ryoshu (local lord).

At the late Heian Period, an increasing number of samurais began to take positions as Azukaridokoro, although it was originally a clerical post, and some continued to advance to acquire the post of Jito (manager and lord of manor) or Zaichi ryoshu (local lord).

sen.j: なお、鎌倉幕府においては、御家人が上司（在京預所）あるいはそれに近い権限を有する上級荘官に補任されることを禁じた「傍官上司」と呼ばれる規定があった。
sen.e: In Kamakura bakufu, there was a regulation called "Bokan ryoshu"(傍官上司), which prohibited gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate) to be appointed as Joshi (上司) （as Zaikyo Azukaridokoro） or high-ranked Sokan (governor of the manor) granted with similar authorities.
sen.cmt: 「傍官上司」→定訳不明："Bokan ryoshu"(傍官上司)[正しい読み方が不明です] 上級荘官→定訳不明：high-ranked Sokan (governor of the manor) としました。
sen.e: In the Kamakura bakufu, there was a regulation called "Bokan ryoshu", which prohibited gokenin (immediate vassals of the shogunate) to be appointed to Joshi (Zaikyo Azukaridokoro) or high-ranked Sokan (governor of the manor) with similar authority.

In the Kamakura bakufu, there was a regulation called 'Bokan joshi,' which prohibited gokenin (immediate vassals of the shogunate) to be appointed to Joshi (Zaikyo Azukaridokoro) or high-ranked shokan (governor of the manor) with similar authority.
sen.cmt: "Bokan ryoshu", を 'Bokan joshi,' に修正しました。high-ranked Sokan を high-ranked shokan に修正しました。

sen.j: これは鎌倉幕府によって正式に補任されて荘園を支配した地頭は荘官としては下司もしくは中司に相当する場合が多く、幕府に仕える御家人が上司となって幕府が補任した同じ御家人である地頭との間に上下関係が発生することを危惧したための規定である。
sen.e: This regulation was formulated by the Kamakura bakufu, because the bakufu was worried about a possible hierarchical disturbance between the gokenins serving to the same bakufu, if a gokenin serving for the bakufu would be appointed to Joshi (上司) (higher-ranked official), while another gokenin officially appointed by the bakufu to the post of Jito, which often corresponded to the lower ranks such as Geshi (lower-ranked officer) and Chushi (中司) (intermediate-ranked officer), in order to control a Shoen manor.

This regulation was formulated by the Kamakura bakufu, because the bakufu was worried about rivalries between the gokenin serving it, if one were appointed to Joshi while another was appointed to the post of Jito, which often corresponded to the lower ranks such as Geshi and Chushi, in order to control a Shoen manor.
sen.cmt: shortened this one quite a bit to improve clarity
sen.e: This regulation was formulated by the Kamakura bakufu, because the bakufu was worried about rivalries between the gokenin serving it, if one were appointed to Joshi while another was appointed to the post of Jito, which often corresponded to the lower ranks such as Geshi and Chushi, in order to control a Shoen manor.
